Vegan until he tastes the salmon that is ;)The plantain chips are good as are the salads. The service is good, they open the bottle for you and pour the wine into small glasses. Don't expect any frills, but definitely worth coming here!delicious !!!

La Isla is the most bang for your buck in Hoboken. I have never been so full (I don't get full), both times I've been to the eatery.The first time we shared the platano asado, a riot of flavors, and a solo croqueta de jamon, filled with ham and fried crisp on the outside. My lunch special masitas de puerco came with super sweet maduros and perfect soupy black beans. Lime brightened the tender fatty pork pieces. My boyfriend had one of the set meals, tasajo con boniato; the spiciness of the braised dry-cured meat went perfectly with the sweet creaminess of the dark potatoes and the crunch of the fried onions and yellow rice tied it all together. Dessert was mind-blowing. Their tres leches is to die for.This second time, we started with the tamale, which did not have all the flavor I associate with La Isla, but it was still good. Once again, I got the pork pieces, which is now an entrée item, not a lunch special, so it was especially huge. My boyfriend got one of the Friday lunch specials: the beef stew. He got his hearty saucy stew with black beans and salty white rice. The meat was tender and well seasoned.Again, we were stuffed. So stuffed we chose not to get dessert (whaaat?!). Despite the little wait and the close quarters, La Isla always delivers on big portions and yummy food.
Felt like the jamon croquettas could have had better ratio of meat. Especially for the price.

I can't stop thinking about how good the meal I had last night here was! The atmosphere is not the greatest. The place is small, nothing fancy, but the service and food is amazing. We got the shrimp and chorizo appetizer and it was incredible. The sauce on it was insanely addictive. I would have drank the bowl when we were done if we weren't in public. This appetizer will not disappoint! The buttery bread they give you is soo good with the sauce too. For the meal I got the stuffed chicken with ham, Swiss, and pickles special. It was fantastic. My boyfriend got the churrasco con chimichurri. He liked it but the steak was a little chewy. The fried yuca and spinach sides were great though! All in all it was a really good meal and I can't wait to go back.

I am a lover of chorizo and their choripan pressed sandwich is pure perfection - grilled chorizo, caramelized onions, and POTATO STICKS, all pressed in Cuban bread.  The combination of salty, sweet, crunchy, and toasty makes a great sandwich.I also tried my husband's pan con lechon sandwich. The roast pork was a bit dry and definitely needed a sauce, a veggie, and other condiments like say potato sticks.  Whenever I come here, it's always for their chorizo sandwich but I'll need to come back on a completely empty stomach to try their Papa Rellena and Platano Asado.  The place is tiny and always crowded so I would come for a late lunch or early dinner.

I am falling more and more in love with this wonderful community restaurant the more I eat here. I can make a meal of their most delicious cuban buttered bread and cafe con leche. But I never do as I can happily order everything on the menu and always over order. The bread reminds me of my grandmother's cooking in both its deliciousness and ability to bring comfort. The cafe con leche is spot on, strong, smooth, just enough milk and like the bread, also comforting, plus a great value. Their yellow rice is perhaps the best I have had anywhere, especially delicious with their moist and flavorful oxtail stew they serve on Thursdays (come for lunch as they may sell out, it's that good). The service is warm, kind, and attentive and is the highlight of the warm atmosphere imbued with salsa music and a colorful interior.
Tiny place with the BEST Cuban food EVER! I always get the shrimp and garlic sauce or the churassco (spelling?) steak...jeez, my mouth waters just thinking about it.

Don't miss trying the papa rellena--amazingly delicious! The pollo asado dish with sweet plantains and yellow rice is delicious--not dry but recommend asking for a side of ranchera sauce for dipping or to pour over as an extra boost of flavor. A Cubaccino was a delicious cap to the meal.

This location is great for a no frills, GOOD breakfast. I love the La Isla Breakfast sandwich and my boyfriend always gets some dish that's basically Ropa Veja with a pouched egg on top. The coffee is nice and strong and will definitely wake you up! If you're looking for a quick, good breakfast-- this is your spot.

I'm all about the island food and this place is sooooo good I'm always getting a potato ball, rice n beans with chicken or the shredded beef or pork whatever it is  (sorry I can't remember what it's called) and the Cuban sandwich. What made me want to try it out in the first place was I thought they had the fried chicken pieces but apparently it's I believe on certain days or times. It's a small place so pick and choose wisely on what day and time you go because it will be packed. I've only had one rude experience there but my friends and I ignored it because we were so starving and didn't want to leave just to find another place AND that was the first time I ever encountered rudeness there with someone I've never seen worked there before but then again I've only been there at left 4 times.
The club sandwich was a disappointment. The empanada was enjoyable. The plantain appetizer was nothing i would order again. disappointed.

Cuban food is not usually my cup of tea and never my choice of a meal especially not for breakfast. But a friend had been raving about the coffee and I heard that this location was on "Diners, Drive Ins, and Dives" and "Throw-down with Bobby Flay," how could I try it?! As a Hoboken native, my breakfast usually consists of coffee and an amazing Jersey bagel on the weekends. But to go to La Isla, you need to get up early, to wait on line, outside, to get a table. The place is tiny and there is usually a wait, especially on the weekends so my friend and I did just that. Was it worth it?! You have NO IDEA. To start, the Cuban coffee was amazing. It was the real deal and worth the wait outside in itself. When it came to choosing my breakfast choice, here is where I got intimidated. I hate breakfast and normally go for fruit or something bland. So after minutes of sweating and perusing the menu, I chose their famous stuffed french toast which was on the throw-down with Bobby Flay. I thought, I like french toast, and Bobby Flay is my fav, so what could go wrong? Well, I was pleasantly surprised and in love. The Cuban flare on this french toast was to die for.  It was your typical french toast with a touch guava and strawberries mixed into a heavenly morning treat...not to mention La Isla beat Bobby Flay in the throw-down. I was so happy I went out of my comfort zone to try this Cuban breakfast. It is a must try and a must visit!
Came to Hoboken to visit Carlos bakery and yelped this little Cuban restaurant. The food was delicious!

Had the Huevos Rancheros take out for breakfast, yum yum yum! I hate taking food to go but I couldn't do another dam egg and cheese sandwich or oatmeal for breakfast. So I indulged in a spicy pool of black beans in a picante tomato sauce, a crispy tortilla, 2 perfectly poached eggs topped with queso blanco and  a side of Moro (rice and beans mixed together). This is completely non traditional for me to have rice in the morning but Jesus Fix It, it was delicious! But left me thinking, what do I have for lunch?... French toast? Lol

Love this place! Their chicken soup is sensational and so addicting! They have a great selection of goodies, as well as daily specials for the week. The only reason it's not 5 stars is that sometimes the staff tends to get a little overwhelmed since it''s a tight location, but always friendly and cheerful. Overall great experience
Hands down the best Cuban place in town. Love the unpretentious air around this tiny establishment. Love the Cuban sandwich (pork)!
Best food in town ., when your looking for Cuban food there is no other destination.. Recently I went to Miami and the food wasn't even close to the quality of LA ISLA .

Had the chance to stop in Hoboken and decided to try this spot. It's very unassuming from the outside and inside a few small tables line the wall. The little kitchen in the back was bustling and several servers were working the few tables which makes me think at normal dining hours(we ate dinner at 4:30) it's busy. I don't eat meat and didn't miss it for one minute while I was eating the veggie empanadas. Absolutely delicious! The bean sauce was amazing. The service was great and the food not only delicious but served beautifully. I'd definitely go back if I had the chance.

Came here on a Thursday night. Busy, good sign. Overall I would say this is a decent spot for Cuban food... But man the thing that will make me come back is that skirt steak... It was beautifully cooked and tasted amazing.. The green sauce that came with it was delicious too.. The rest of the food was just ok and they ran out with the specials by 8pm.... Pork chops were a little dry and sides were just ok. Service was pretty good. If I return, it will be for the steakSad theres no half star options. I would give the steak a 4.5 and other foods a barely passing rate...

Not much has changed in 15 years but some new floors, paint, and a bunch of colorful pictures, newspaper writeups & photographs that adorn the walls!-Lunch is always busy. -The place is tiny. -Greeting is luke warm. -Service is indifferent- once they seat you they take the order, look away and then walk away basically mid-ordering. You definitely feel rushed here because they want to get as many people in and out.-The papa relleno is stupendous--seasoned ground beef and creamy mashed potatoes in a perfect breaded ball with spicy red sauce.-Cafe con leche is unmatched--strong Cuban coffee with just the right amount of warm milk and foam!-The Cuban sandwich has gone downhill--the pork is tough and overall lacks taste. Needs more mustard too. I remember La Isla when it was a REAL divey (moreso than today) hole in the wall! The food was fantastic and the service was the same as today...Eh.  Oh well!This is one of those places you just tolerate the lack of warmth and friendliness because it's well priced, very tasty, and so authentic.

We have been to La Isla for dinner several times and never been overly impressed.  But knowing everyone loves it we keep coming back.  This was our first shot at brunch.  We got the omelette with chorizo, mango and caramelized onions.  It was nothing beyond your typical omelette.  It came with Cuban toast, which was served probably 10 minutes before the dish.  Odd.  Also the toast is uber buttered.  I will say the omelette was much better put on the toast as a sandwich.  Their green habanero hot sauce is a must but warning on the level of spice.  We also ordered Omar's famous French toast. I warn you now it is A LOT.  I could only eat half a piece and could not eat the center bite with all the cream cheese.  I would have liked more of a crunch.  If you must order this I recommend splitting this dish if possible.  The service was better then previous visits but still just mediocre.

Soooo I came here to try the famous Omar's stuffed French toast and I didn't realize that they do not serve it all day... GRRRR only until 11am or until 3pm on sunday for brunch.  Pros- BYOB, on Washington, outdoor seating, friendly service, prices, coconut mango cheesecake, and papa rellenaSandwiches-  the Cuban and pan con bistec were just ok..BATHROOM IS SUPER TINY!I will be back for the French toast!

So, I've never actually been here to eat a meal but I stopped there today to grab a quick snack for my toddler and I. Two chicken empanadas were $10. Talk about inflation. They were okay tasting but definitely not for that price. I can get 7 for 10 in neighboring towns. I should've known better. It was packed so I'm sure the food is tasty but those prices just turned me off. Even for Hoboken.

Been here for lunch a few times. It's ok Cuban food. A step above Tina's in the city but not what you expect from a proper Cuban place. Lechon asado was lacking really mojo flavor. Pollo asado more flavorful mainly because of onions. Empanadas are standard. Cuban sando was nothing special.

Ordered the Fritas today, which are 3 small chorizo and meat patties sliders. Tasted awful. The meat was burnt and dry. I didn't taste chorizo at all. I even added ketchup in the hopes of moistening up the burgers, but it didn't work at all. Drank a lot of water at lunch...I wished I had gotten something else off the menu.

After a business trip to NYC, I stopped in La Isla on my way out for a quick bite with a couple friends. It's two doors down from a beer & wine store, which is perfect because La Isla is a BYO. They don't seat you until your entire party is present, which was annoying, especially since it was a Tuesday evening and the restaurant was much closer to empty than it was full. I had the masitas de puerco, which consisted of fried chunks of pork with raw red onion on top. The meat was a tad chewy and didn't seem to be marinated at all, but my sides of yuca and black beans added some flavor that the meat lacked. My friends seemed to enjoy their meals more--a salad with shrimp, and smoked salmon on a black bean/rice cake with guacamole on top. For dessert, we split the tres leches cake, which was phenomenal.

Excellent Cuban food for a really great price.  I love this hidden gem.  I have brought many friends and even business clients to this place for a truly "authentic" Cuban cuisine.  It's not high end, but it's high quality.

Growing up with a cuban mother, this was like going home again (without an expensive flight). Service and food were ON POINT. it was delicious and well presented. I would go here for every meal if my boyfriend would let me.I can't say enough good things about this place. It's SO good! Word to the wise though, brunch always has a long wait :(

Big tastey dishes at an unexpected  side restaurant. Had a salad with oranges mango avocado and spinach. Yuca side dish was large enough to take home. Black beans and rice had mixed in pork for amazing flavor. Hole in the wall but it makes you feel like you're dining in Miami

Great spot for brunch.  The three of us each had the Ropa Vieja (skirt steak) and shared an order of pancakes which was perfect, because an order came with 3 of them.  The generous portion of skirt steak was very flavorful and tender. It came served with rice, eggs, and a side of black beans.  Tried the cubaccino drink which was a bit disappointing.
My favorite cuban spot. The food is great and the cafe con leche is awesome.

BRUNCH REVIEWThe deets:1. BYOB!!!2. Brunch ends at 3p. 3. Restaurant gets cray around 1p.4. Cafe con leche is the truth, the way and the light. Get it! 5. BYOB!!!6. Price points - mega cheap! Surprising, considering this restaurant's popularity. 7. Setting - small and modest. Diner-esque in style, with some Cuban flair added for character. 8. The eats - muy bueno.  I ordered the maduro, spinach & queso blanco omelette, [served with home fries and toast -  $9.00] Screw your diet and get the CUBAN BREAD instead of regular, boring 'healthy' bread. 9. About their famous stuffed french toast - This did not live up to the hype. While the guava stuffing was delicious, the bread itself was entirely too hard, akin to pie crust. 10. But that BYOB tho... #praises #popbottles #CHEAPBRUNCHI'm about this place. Will definitely be back!

A friend had been wanting to try this place out for a while (apparently it was featured on Guy Fieri's Diners, Drive-Ins and Dives : Food Network). So we came by a week ago on a week night. - BYOB. - Packed! It's a hole in the wall, very casual, very small place. The food is good & very reasonably priced...but you get what you pay for...the steak wasn't the greatest I've had. Neither was the tres leches. Appetizers were better. Loved their Papa Rallena.So for what it is & the price range it's in.....it was good.

I'm not too sure about this place. Service is good and food is decent.  The chicken soup was my favorite.  I am cuban so maybe that's why I'm not convinced on the taste of food.  I have to say there is only one cuban in the whole eatblishment.

Holy oxtail! Love coming here for lunch. It is usually packed on the weekends for their guava french toast featured on the Food Network but I prefer salty so I prefer lunch on the weekdays to avoid a wait. My favorite lunch special is their oxtail special. It is hard to a place who makes fall off the bone but still intact oxtails. For those don't know oxtails are just beef on the bone. Think of a short rib but more tender when cooked properly as they do here. They also make a killer cubano sandwich (ham, Swiss and roast pork panini), cuban coffee (dark roast with steamed milk) and what I call a "potato ball" (huge softball-sized orbs of mashed potato with a Latin-flavored ground beef center that is flash fried till crunchy that can be a meal by itself).You'll pay twice what you pay 10 minutes away in North Bergen's Little Cuba but eating here saves me the trip and to be honest it's cleaner. Take away a star because I think they use MSG so it can get a bit salty even for me. My workaround? Eat everything with more rice. Everyone needs more rice in their lives.

Came to La Isla to try Omar's Strawberry Guava cream cheese stuffed French toast. It was AMAZING and I can see why he beat out Bobby Flay. I especially liked that it was crunchy. I had a bite of my boyfriend's chorizo manchego omelet and it was also so very delicious. The eggs were perfectly done -- soft and fluffy. I would highly recommend La Isla and the prices are very reasonable!

If you order anything else here other than the Cuban, Medianoche, papa rellanas (meat stuffed crispy potato ball), Guava and cream cheese stuffed french toast you are dumb. Sure they have other items on their menu but it's all fluff. The above are the stars here and must gets. Service is casual yet friendly. I felt like a regular after one visit. Prices, affordable. I could eat here a few days a week without feeling guilty. The portions are generous for the pennies paid. I am always full after one half of my sandwich but I finish it all bc there is no way i can let something that delicious go to waste. I also never leave without having a cafe con leche and sometimes I stop by just for that.Best Cuban sandwich outside of Havana and San Pedro California.
Great authentic Cuban food. Service excellent, atmosphere cosy, great music y la comida era muy delisiosa.
First time here after seeing in it on TV a while back. I had Ropa Vieja, delicious and good service!
Wonderful dinner!  Hosted my son who lives nearby.  We ate at the counter and loved the interaction with all the employees.  This is a BYOB place so if you want to drink bring it!Recommend easily.
Good food but expensive for the daily menu, taste was alright, I would suggest to them cook less salty

La Isla is a timeless and consistent restaurant. I've been going ever since I was a little kid with my parents. My classic order has always been a beef empanada, pan con lechon (sometimes with a side of their crispy hot delicious French fries), and for dessert, their key-lime pie. Every single thing they make, including their meals like Ropa Vieja or their soups, is so tasty. Their entire staff is so nice. Definitely somewhere to visit and grab a bite to eat if you're in Hoboken, or even from New York City!!!

Great price. Great food. My boyfriend and I decided to go here for our anniversary since he's new to the area. He loved it and is totally on the fan club now! It was also his first time trying mamey and I'm certain he's going to stop by once a week for a beverage!

Cuban food at such a reasonable price!  I love this little place in Hoboken, and its a good go to for either lunch or dinner.  The papa rellena and the Cuban sandwiches are two things you must try here.  Service is fast and friendly here as well!

My absolute favorite in Hoboken.When I interned on Washington St, i used to come here all the time and order the papa rellena and the roast pork lunch special with rice and black beans. I never finished the lunch special because it's too filling. Overall, I've loved every dish I tried there :) And it's pretty affordable. Highly recommend!
Great food. Super fast service. Real authentic Cuban food. They serve one hard to find item around here: pan con mantequilla tostado (toasted Cuban bread with butter) - delicious.
Great place with delicious food and an awesome atmosphere.  Got there a little early, so did not have to wait.  I know they also have a big carry out business.

I'm easily impressed by good food so I notice I tend to give out 4-5 star ratings quite often.   However, this place is well-deserved as the food was delicious.  We had lunch here and ordered the El Cubano sandwich and Spinach salad with steak. Both were really good and we'd consider ordering the same next time we go.  You also get great value for your money here.   The drawback of this restaurant is the size of its dining room. It's quite the cozy little restaurant, and unless you get a seat on the patio, you might feel like you're sitting at a table of 30.

I probably ate here before my Yelp era but I decided I needed to go back to La Isla. The first time I stopped by, I walked right out because the place was packed so obviously people love it. It's a place to get a quick and affordable lunch considering the prices around Hoboken.I'm happy I gave it a try but I probably wouldn't come back. My rice was cold. the pollo asado was lacking in flavor. My yuca fries, which I normally would inhale, were just OK. Since I live in JC now, I'm going to remain loyal to Rumba's Cafe which offers bigger portions, lots more flavor, and at HALF the price. ONE empananda costs $4....Rumbas has them for a $1. But I understand it's all about location!

Love La Isla downtown great food & staff ( ridiculous they no longer deliver,)Uptown same great food only they do not cook the food the same way...if you're going for brunch they do not put fruit inside pancakes as they do downtown ( lazy)They now only deliver from uptown location  $20.00 minimum delivery ---downtown never a minimum so high...  :-(

Writing a review in hopes the owners will read it...Always ordered from the Washington street location. AMAZING food, great portions.Went to the new Maxwell location for dinner once and got takeout once. Much smaller portions that are not worth the $20 something meal, the shrimp with white wine and garlic sauce had no garlic at the bottom (which is my favorite part), and hardly covered the shrimp which were noticeably smaller, I asked for boiled yuca and got fried ( it's very busy at the restaurant so maybe they didn't hear me ask for boiled) and the black beans were only half filled in the container (again with the smaller portions).The downtown location needs to give the uptown location a few pointers. The location is great, the restaurant has a lively atmosphere, so it would be a shame if it didn't end up meeting the standards we're all used to from the downtown location.
I'll keep it short and sweet: do yourself a favor and get the pollo asado. Great meal for a great price!

I've had the cuban sandwich here a few times and each time I hope it gets better. I want it to be awesome so bad, but it's just lacking a bit. The pork isn't very well seasoned and has also been pretty fatty every time I've gotten it. All in all, their cuban just seems lacking to me.

Came in for brunch and had the churrasco al caballo, huevos rancheros and their famous stuffed French toast.  The food was all delicioussss albeit all of it was a little cold.  Even with the temperature problems it tasted great, though, so I didn't care.  I also had a mango coconut batido which was insanely good.  It's a really small space so I recommend getting there early...it's tough to find a spot but they do a pretty good job of turning tables.  Not the type of place to go and relax for hours...get in, get your food and get out so that someone else can sit!
Very good, especially for brunch, but you should have a backup plan if you're coming on the weekend as it is always very busy.

The garlic chicken (Pollo Al Ajillo con Espinica), you'll have to translate the Spanish as I'm too lazy, was nasty. I love La Isla. Period. But they need to do something about their chicken breasts. The chicken breast is extremely tough and just isn't pleasant to chew on. If I am suspecting correctly, it seems like it wasn't tenderized, was frozen, taken directly from the freezer, and placed on the grill. This is unacceptable if that is the case. Everything else was great. If you don't believe me on my chicken, order it and tell me how tender it is or if it was a rubbery disgusting texture. I'll update my review after two weeks when I try it again to be certain this wasn't a one-off.

I used to come to this place quite often as the food was good and closer to Path.However，my experience was dropped from 4 to 3 stars now.  I often ordered the steak which was dryer each time when I stopped by.  The waitress kept on forgetting my water though I was sitting right in front of her at counter.  The rice was saggy.  I really want to learn to like this place again but have a hard time to do so.Perhaps I should try it again 6 months later....

Papa rellena all the way!While I have enjoyed many different dishes from there, the PR is my staple. Cheap yet rich in flavor, it is a delicious bang for your buck.  I always get at least two with my side of green sauce. The only complaint is that they are not as hot as I would like temperature wise.  While I am sure there are at proper food temperatures, it would be nice when something is made in advance you pop it in the 400 degree oven for 5 minutes.Seating can be nonexistent at peak hours so be prepared to wait or choose take out instead.

I took a client here for lunch at the request of a long-time Hoboken resident. We went at 1PM on a Tuesday and snagged the last table. Our waiter was prompt with the water and to take our order. I got the Havana Club and it was GREAT. The ingredients were so fresh and I could taste the quality. My client is a regular and always gets the roasted chicken. This place comes highly recommended for brunch and I've been told you have to get there early!
Mediocre food although the papa rellena was light and flakie my masitas de puerco were dry and flavorless. Attitude from the staff added to my woes. Very disappointed.

Delicious Cuban food in the heart of Hoboken. Great for a tasty brunch or lunch with friends and family. Love love love their papa rellena and their sandwiches are to die for. Top two sandwiches are the original Cuban and the chicken avocado sandwiches! Definitely a must try and gem in Hoboken.

This is the first time ever that Yelp has failed me (and my bf). We were visiting Jersey from Manhattan and excited to try this place but everything was awful. My shrimp dish was too salty, his chicken was bland, the rice is the parboiled fake kind (he's a Dominican and rejected it), the beans were ok. Got  stomach ache afterwards. Nice staff but the food is awful.

Sliders were decent. Pan con bistec was complete garbage, totally dry and inedible. And this was the one thing they were supposed to get right, if they consider themselves a Cuban place. For this reason, I can't give more than 2 stars.Also, the service is severely lacking. When we stepped inside, there was host or anyone we ask to seat us. After waiting around for 10 minutes, we asked a woman at the bar if we could get a seat. She said, "you have to wait till someone cleans the table," with a bit of attitude. There were 2 empty, clean tables right there!

Cute little Cuban restaurant! I went on a double date there for my first time. My boyfriend and I loved it! Great portions and pretty good options. I had the chicken with spinach and a side of rice & beans. Really filling and flavorful. This spot is perfect for date night!

I love La Isla.  Growing up in Hudson County I know there is a lot of good (and cheaper) Cuban food out there.  Normally, it would be hard for me to justify paying a premium just to have a meal in Hoboken but there is definitely something about La Isla that keeps me coming.  I think mostly it's the vibe.  I love/hate the cozy nature of the place.  Love it when I can find a seat but too often it is packed.  I am hoping the expansion to 12th street helps with this.  I have been here a bunch of times and have never been disappointed with a meal.  My personal favorite is shooting over for lunch and having a papa rellena along with one of their many sandwich choices.  But make sure to get there right at noon or slightly before if possible to ensure you beat the crowd.

A friend took me to this place for breakfast. She had been raving about it for weeks and I can honestly say is was fantastic. The flavors were like nothing I have tasted before. Hash browns with steak, eggs and rice and beans.  From the coffee to the French toast with guava and strawberries I can't think of any breakfast that I have had that was this good in a VERY long time.
With the exception of my mothers homeCooked Cuban food, this is amazing feel likeYour in Miami cooking.
La Isla is a good place. The stuffed french toast is legitimate. I have always enjoyed it. Their specials are good, too. I also enjoy their cafe con leche.
This place rocks! La Isla is a gem on Washington Street in Hoboken. Great for brunch and/or lunch.

It is SO nice to give a place 5 stars.  It's been a while.  This might, hands down, be my favorite place in Hoboken.  Highly unsuspecting given its modest decor, but don't be fooled, these people KNOW how to cook.  And they know how to cook CUBAN with bold flavors.  I came here for breakfast (not to be confused with brunch, because their star item, is not offered after 12).  They do not take reservations, but my friend and I were lucky to snag a table after just a few minutes of waiting (come in 2's- the place is small). Judging by how breakfast, I would come here for any meal: lunch, brunch, or dinner.  I had the famous Omar's French Stuffed French Toast- which was won a Bobby Flay Throw Down (La Isla has also been featured on Guy Fier's Diners, Dive in and Dives among a thousand of other press mentions).  It's truly a tasty, inventive, dish.  It surprises you too- if you don't usually dig sweet for breakfast (and I don't), trust me, you'll like this french toast because it's not overly sweet.  It's actually more tart- 3 fluffy pieces of fried egg bread, stuffed with strawberries and cream cheese, crusted in almond and corn flakes, doused in guava sauce that is more tart than sugary.  It's a steal for $9- I felt so sick after almost eating all of it, but I wanted to lick my plate. My friend got the huevos rancheros, $12 which was a lot of food.  Poached eggs in a basket of black beans, delectable spicy tomato sauce, all in a fresh tortilla, and a generous side of white rice (you can opt for yellow).  We split a side of Spanish chorizo, which refreshingly, was not just a mass produced link of red sausage.  It was homemade, char grilled, smokey AND fatty at the same time.  They give you 4 half for $3.50.My friend and I each ordered a Cuban Latte which was STRONG and awesome.  A big, hot mug of cafe con lots of leche.Service was fast (a little too fast and rushed..given they put my plate down on top of my silverware x_x).    Definitely worth returning.
Food was amazing! Service was fast and the staff was really friendly. They also have fresh flowers on the tables which I loved ! Can't wait to go back :)

La Isla is a long-ago bookmarked spot for us.  Ever since we saw Guy Fieri making those "omg, this is so good!" statements on the Food Network's Diners, Drive-ins and Dives, we knew we had to get our rear ends over here.  In a last-minute, spur of the moment decision, we decided to change route and head into Hoboken for some famous Cuban food instead.  We ordered the following to share as a table:Papa Rellena, AShrimp Ceviche, ASpinach Salad w Grilled Chicken, AChicken Habanero, B+Tasajo (featured on the Food Network), CThe Papa Rellena (fried potato ball with beef) is a must-order item.  Shrimp Ceviche is nice and light, goes very well with the plantain chips.  We all liked the Spinach Salad with Grilled Chicken.  It had a light citrusy tang, and I could've easily eaten that without the chicken.  My sister and the novio were really fond of the grilled chicken that came with the salad, but not as fond of the Chicken Habanero; I was of the opposite opinion.  I really liked the crispness of the Chicken Habanero, but the grilled chicken had a bit too much char flavor.  Maduros were a bit too burnt for my liking.  The Tasajo was only okay in my opinion, meat and yuca in the dish were both rather dry.   We are unlikely to order this again.  Service is incredibly rushed and they don't bother with doing more than the bare minimum.  All in all,  a rather disappointing experience, especially after Guy's glowing review, but they take a solid 3.  In comparison to other Cuban restaurants in NJ though (a la Cuban Pete's in Montclair), they've got a lot of catching up to do.

La Isla's proximity to my job is a problem. (1 I'd rather not have fixed.)After the great bust that was dinner at Sabor Latin Bistro on Monday, I was fiending for some delicious picadillo. Picadillo just happens to be 1 of the Thursday lunch specials at La Isla for $10...don't mind if I do!Went in for a late lunch at 3pm, the restaurant was still pretty poppin' but I still got a seat right away. I knew exactly what I wanted, didn't even need to open the menu. Ordered my picadillo, and it was being served to me 7min later. (Hashtag winning again) It was a healthy portion of rice and picadillo, but yo...the black beans that came in a bowl on the side, were EVERYTHING! They were so flavorful and cooked so well (not mushy), I found myself eating them more than the picadillo I had been craving. I was in and out in under 40min...perfect lunch time experience. Cheap and fast, just how I like 'em...RESTAURANTS! I still haven't had dessert or brunch here. This saddens me. Perhaps I will rectify both this weekend. Go to here. You won't be disappointed.

The food here is great & the portions are big! It's a small restaurant but it's fine, I never felt crowded. I got the pork chops & they were seasoned perfectly! My bf got the chicken in some kind of white sauce with sautéed spinach  the sauce was the sooooooo flavorful! Overall great but I like the new uptown location a little better

The food is great,the place is very clean and is BYOB, my only issue with this place is that the 3 times I been there the server is always rushing us, the first time he told me u had to order fast 9:15pm,the second time if I waned everything wrapped around 9:40pm and the last time 8:45pm same server told me I had to order fast because they were closing. I will be back. And yes I recommend this place. Papas rellenas,Salmón,pan con bistec are my fav.

1st time here....we walked in and waited by door to be greeted but after about 5 min. I asked the rude server who i tell to be seated...she didnt look at me and walked by me pointed her finger and says put your own name there... I seen her do this to all 8 people that came in...but then we sat ourselves at the diner type counter. The guys there were so nice..and gave us the best service. They were just as busy as Ms. Rude but still had a smile. So our food came and it was amazing!!! So the men service and the food over powered Ms. Rude and deserved 5 stars.

I ordered food by phone, cuz ordering on Grubhub doesn't work. I called around 10:55am which the breakfast hour should be closing soon. Fact, I ordered delivery for Omar's stuff toast which everything recommended on Yelp! However, the lady (who has a bit accent) who talked to me was really patient and nice!! She told me that they only delivery for lunch! But I asked her if it could possible for me to get the stuffed toast with my other order of lunch. She asked me to hold on a second, quickly she turned back and asked me whether I would mind the toast would not be warm when the food get delivered to me. I said yes and got my stuffed toast a bit warm when I got them！ I ordered Omar's stuffed toast and roast chicken (thigh) with plantain and yellow rice (which the lady recommended me), and French fries. The Omar's stuffed toast is not amazing but pretty good! The filling inside the sandwich is perfectly sweetened! I wouldn't feel heavy when I finished a whole piece of stuffed toast. But 1 piece of it is very filling to me tho! The roast chicken is good, too! The yellow rice is not strongly flavoured (good thing) n not bland as all. However, in general all dishes I had here so far are not strongly flavoured by spices or sauces. The rice and chicken could have a bit stronger flavoured. Other than that, they are all good :)) I can taste the really food from here! Not too strong, but not to light! Like home food, tasted Just right!

This restaurant is usually packed on the weekends and usually has a 15 to 30 minute wait. I wasn't fortunate enough to sit on a table so service was a little lacking. The hot chocolate was nice and refreshing with a lot of whipped cream. Now most people are aware that Bobby Flay is infamous for tasting Omar's french toast but I have to say if you're not a fan of sweet foods like myself you will not enjoy this. It's definitely not your traditional soft french toast , instead filled with strawberries, guava & covered in frosted flakes and almonds. I would recommend it as a dessert item not a breakfast item. The El basero was delicious, moist and made the wait well worth it, I was given a very large portion for $14. This Cuban place has tons of sandwiches to choose from but since there's pork in them you guys let me know how they are since I'm not a pork eater.

The stuffed french toast is alright. I had very high expectations when I came, but the french toast did not live up to them. It was a little dry, and I wouldn't go out of my way to have the french toast. The restaurant is also very small; I wouldn't suggest going with more than four people.

Hoboken has free parking on Sunday, resulting a situation of over parking. It seems like there is always some free spot near the post office (4 blocks from La Isla).The lunch hour ends at 3pm on Sunday. We arrived at 2:57. Anyhow, we sat at the table near the entrance and a couple of guys arrived after us were turned away. It was kind of noisy due to the loud music. My spinach salad was great. The combination of mango, blue cheese, and avocado has some unique flavor. One thing they can improve is to use fresh spinach instead of the one from jumbo bag, so the rotten leaves can be spotted and be taken out. My wife's Pan con Lechon sandwich was in average. The beef has deli taste; the bread was left outside for too long and was bone dry. We did have difficulties to communicate with waiters due to language issue as they all speak Spanish. We took a takeout menu and explained to Him that I would need it for writing review. He repeatedly took it from our table back to the counter...Overall, I give it four stars.

You'd be hard pressed to find a better meal at an affordable price in Hoboken. La Isla has one of the best chefs in the country. Great Cuban sandwiches and coffee. Hoboken has shockingly few real good places to eat. Most restaurants (and businesses) go down in the first year. La Isla is the real deal. I try to get there early to get a table, but don't mind sitting at the old style lunch counter when I'm alone. Nice mixed and diverse crowd. A++++
Wife and I went last night because she saw it on Dinners and Dives.  Good authentic food.  It is a really small place / dive but the food presentation is what you expect from a formal restaurant.
Cute little spot. Feels very authentic and love the music they always play. The Cuban latte, papa Rellena, pan cubano and choripan are delicious! Place is small so plan ahead!

Stopped in late afternoon midweek & wow what a place.  Got the roast chicken lunch special, one of four specials, with a pick of two sides for only $12.50.   My food was in front of me in less than 3 minutes.  Fresh, hot & well presented.  I went with the yellow rice & beans as my sides.  The chicken breast was moist & flavorful, the rice & black beans spot on, but I kicked it up a bit with green yucateco hot sauce.   The sweating soon followed.  Topped it off with Cuban coffee.  Who needs Havana when you have La Isla, Hoboken baby!!

La Isla is always a great spot to grab a bite. I stopped by today for Sunday brunch and it was packed as usual. We didn't have to wait too long for a table. I ordered la papa a stuffed potato with bacon and egg cheese and ranchero sauce. Very tasty. My friend got el basero which is ropa vieja over white rice with 2 poached eggs and a side of beans. Beyond having a little portion envy I liked my meal very much. May need to stop in for dinner for some ropa vieja though.

Best Cuban spot in the area.  That includes Sophies in lower Manhattan.Try the stuffed French Toast, but don't do it unless you brought your appetite, because the portions are huge.It is a tiny little place right off Washington Street, but the coffee is great and the people are nice.

Four of us came on a Saturday night to try out this highly recommended Cuban restaurant. In true BYOB fashion, we brought two bottles of wine and two beers to split between all of us. We ordered the ceviche, pollo empanada, and the papa rellena to start. The papa rellena was the most memorable and unique dish. The other two were forgettable. For entrees, we ordered the chicken with spinach and chorizo pot roast. The chicken with the cream sauce was great, the sauce was not too heavy but provides the right amount of creamy strength to make the chicken tasty. The chorizo dish was slightly dry. Service was fast, restaurant is slightly crowded but overall I had a very good time and would come back again!
So good that I took the garlic sauce + rice...brought it onboard...flew it all the way back to California.Portions are GIGANTIC.

Walked in past the the outdoor dining area. No one was at the host stand, but we could see all the tables were full, so we bellied up to the bar. It's a diner, and a small one. Seating is tight. The place was bustling at 8 on a Friday. Our server, Yosenia, was deep in the weeds, but never took it out on us, quick with a smile and very friendly.We got the papa rellena to start. Think grape fruit sized, tater tot consistency outside, shepherds pie inside. The mashed potato filling was buttery and creamy. Could have had more ground beef at the center. The best part was the salsa ranchero that came with it, smoky with heat that snuck up on you. Get the salsa! Good but I probably wouldn't order again because everything else was better and the portions are massive here. Need to save real estate in the belly.Entrees were pollo al ajillo with arroz con gandules and tostones as the sides and churrasco with spinach and French fries for the sides. My chicken was slammin'. The chicken itself was at least a pound of flesh covered in garlic and herbs over a bed of perfectly sautéed spinach, not overcooked, swimming in a tangy white garlic sauce that I would drink out of a mug. Oh. So. Amazing. Tostones were pretty good but I was kind of wishing i'd gotten the maduros instead when they came walking by. Will do next time. The yellow rice with pigeon peas was tasty, but I only had room for a few bites.  My man's churrasco was okay. Also a huge portion and the chimichurri that came on the side was dee-lish. The fries are very cute shoestring fries that were super crispy.Though I had no room left, I insisted on tres leches. Their version is unique in that in comes in a ramekin and is covered in meringue. The sponge was denser than I'm accustomed to, and this version was less sweet than some others I've had. My sweet tooth is on steroids, so not my exact preference, but I still devoured every morsel. Those without a strong sweet tooth will probably love this version of the dessert. I saw a key lime pie walk by after I ordered. That looked incredible with a massively thick graham cracker crust. I def have to try that next time.I also am dying to try the soups, salmon entree, and arroz con pollo based on what I saw.This is one of those instances in which not every thing was 5 star, but the overall experience was great and there are so many things I want to go back for that they get the nod. It's not just for French toast. Run here for dinner!
My tastebuds are SUPER PLEASED! The food was amazing; the staff was very friendly and attentive! Random choice for early morning breakfast; we will be back!

It has been a while since my last visit to La Isla, and it is still as good as I remember it to be.  La Isla is an institution in Hoboken, of the handful of cuban restaurants in the mile square, this is the best for good reasons.  For me the best reason is the Pollo a la Ajillo con Espinaca, I never thought a chicken breast dish can be made so juicy and tasty.  This is a must for me each time I come here, coupled with a cold morir sonando, it's a perfect meal for any night.  It was a rainy saturday night, so we got lucky in getting our seats pretty quickly at the bar.  If you don't mind squeezing in with your fellow patrons, the bar is definitely the way to go.  All of the staffs are very friendly and attentive as they run around behind the bar.

La Isla is deceiving as it appears old and run down from the outside...but I have been here twice for dinner and will keep going back. The restaurant has phenomenal, authentic Cuban food.  Menu is a good size with a variety of types of food. I have had fish and beef from here and both I would order again. Portions are large and appetizers are good for sharing.  Service was great on both occasions. Of note, restaurant is BYOB.  There is very limited seating during the winter, maybe seating for about 10 people.  There is an outside area in the warmer weather that accommodates a few more people. Would definitely recommend La Isla - probably the best dinner I have had in Hoboken!

After FINALLY coming to Hoboken on a gloriously sunny day, I made my way over to La Isla and can honestly say it was one of my favorite dining experiences of the year. The restaurant is on the small side and as expected, relatively crowded when we entered. After a few moments however, we were promptly notified by the personable employees that the wait time wouldn't be more than a few minutes and thankfully we were seated shortly thereafter. After devouring the famous Papa Rellena appetizer to start and the succulent daily special (Fricasse de Pollo) a few minutes afterwards, any further words will only fail to do this place justice. Suffice it to say, La Isla represents in my opinion, perhaps the apotheosis of unpretentious home style dining in Hoboken.

On a trip to hoboken we came across this Great restaurant. Very authentic dishes and the taste is great. Me and my boyfriend arrived when it was packed, but they sat us down pretty quickly and our service was not half bad, considering how packed it was. We watched as they made the cuban sandwhich, it came out oh so crisp and filled with flavor, and for dessert we ordered mango glazed cheescake it was the perfect ending to the meal. I would definately be a regular if i lived in the area.

We stumbled upon this gem of a place when we were in the hoboken area and can i just say it is the most popping place in such a tiny place. After about. 15 min wait we were seated and because we stumbled upon this place without really yelping we didn't really know what to expect. But it was the best experience with cuban food we had in jersey. We first started with the Ceviche as an appetizer and it was just bomb.com. Very good and very fruity with a slight tangy taste. I have no other words to describe it other than  you can not pass on this one.  The Choripan was definitely an authentic cuban sandwich and it wasn't over or under cooked but just right, with the right amount of crisp. Now the desserts alone should receive a separate rating because the restaurant can operate as a dessert bar alone with their Coconut Mango Cheesecake and Tres Leches. I'm not a big fan of Coconut, Mango  or cheesecake but they somehow managed to satisfy my tastebuds with all three as a combo and I have to say I can't complain and they did a pretty damn good job of it. Tres Leches was definitely on the sweeter side, but then again it is tres leches. No other words than you be the judge. This restaurant has a lot of hits and rarely any misses, and if you are on the go and need a quick bite, just get their empanadas to go because it will definitely make you come back for more.
Omar's Stuffed French Toast is superb! Very friendly staff, cute cozy atmospehere

This is just like mom's home cooking.  The location is a typical Cuban cafeteria.  Counter and a few tables.  Get past the pretentious Hoboken residents and the meal is delicious, warm, and satisfying.  The last time I was there I had my favorite cuban meal:  Rabo Encedido (ox tail stew), yuca herbida (boiled yuca), and congris (black beans and rice).  The accompanying sides were as always, well seasoned and delicious.  The ox tail was tender without being overcooked.  The meat separated from the bone very nicely and cleanly.  The sauce was thick and tasty.  This is always a welcome meal.  This is my second go to spot for Cuban.  My mom's house will always be first.

Went for breakfast with my boyfriend both of us were very pleased he got an omelette with cheese and spinach (cheese was light fresh and fluffy.) I got Omar's stuffed french toast, which was on Throwdown with Bobby Flay, it was more of a dessert but sooo delicious! The bread was sweet and flaky and the inside was creamy. Definitely would visit again :)

I love this place.  It's small place and gets packed quickly so usually I grab a seat at the bar.  Service is very quick yet abrupt, they want tables to go in and out.  The papa relleno is great, must get it with the hot sauce!  I was not impressed by the french toast but maybe because I'm not a big french toast fan.  The salmon is delicious and so are the steak dishes, very tender.  I felt that the tres leches dessert was a little too soggy and sweet, but I loved the cheesecake and the flan.  Cuban coffee is super strong and delicious.
Really amazing good Spanish coffee in this quaint small restaurant where you can sit by the bar and enjoy it or sit outside in front as you watch people walk by!

I have been wanting to go here for a long time and I decided to take the train there. It's on the famous Washington Street where you can find all kinds of different restaurants, bars, etc. so I had Ropa Vieja (Shredded Flank Steak) with rice and peas and plantains. I also had Papa Rellena (mashed potato stuffed with ground beef) and then breaded and fried.
Plantains good.. Rice good... Beans good.. flan amazing... Love this place ;)FYI this place is byob...
I've never had a bad meal here which is why it has remained my mainstay destination for top quality Cuban cuisine for more than 20 years

Had a great roasted pork, ham, swiss and pickle sandwich, on this amazing sweet bread.  A nice garlic mojo to add some additional Sass.  A great place, and I understand now why people rave about this place.  Has a diner feel, not a huge place, but boy do they pack some love into their food!  Thumbs up.
Let me be clear....we moved back to Chicago and here I sit thinking about how great the food and coffee is at La Isla.I really miss this place!!!

Papa Rellena is kind of greasy. But the crispy crust, soft potato and fragrant meat stuffing worth the risk of getting fat. The creativity of combining the ordinary potato and meat together is also terrific!
The food is inexpensive and delicious. What everyone says about this place is spot on. It's a must go to.
Very authentic food, great service , small homely place

To be fair, my review is based on the Cuban sandwich only. I had hopes for this place, but I'm disappointed to say it was the worse Cuban sandwich I've ever had. The pork was extremely dry and it appeared like someone left out the butter. Not what I expected at all. I'll give other dishes a try next time.

We were super excited to try the new uptown location but it was so disappointing!! We basically have a Cuban diner in prime restaurant space. The food was mediocre at best. Much better spots in Hoboken for Cuban food. We couldn't wait to try everything based on all the reviews but after we waited an hour and a half for our food, we slowly started to wonder. The food came out luke warm and was lacking something, can't put my finger on it. I guess the quality reminded me of a high end diner and I love diners but just not what we were expecting. The sangria was the worst I've ever had, tasted like cheap fruit juice, no alcohol, no fruit. Service was horrendous but will chalk that up to just opening. The restaurant itself felt institutional, and was so beyond loud that the 4 of us stopped talking bc we were screaming. They even addressed that they have a sound issue. Overall, we were expecting an authentic, fun, quality experience and we left disappointed with hopes that it gets better? Maybe we'll try again in a few months.
Excellent food. Glad I found this place on Yelp, it kept me out of the chain restaurant my Co worker wanted to go to.

I LOVE this place. I honestly don't care about the service, the food is way too good to even notice. The joint is super small, I mean really small. It probably has only 6 tables that seat 4 or 5, some bar seats, and 4 outside tables. But I really think that's what cuban food is all about, homey, nothing fancy and cozy. You'll hear awesome spanish music in the background but it's not too loud so that's a plus, nice decor, a bunch of pictures everywhere on the walls and a little flower in the table all the time. I always try to make it there for lunch, lunch food is always better than dinner food at La Isla, plus it's much cheaper. The arroz con pollo is awesome! Almost as good as my friend's mom's. Honestly, restaurants can't beat a spanish mom's food but La Isla was pretty close. They fry their maduros soooo well. I love it. Slightly crisp on the outside and wonderfully sweet on the inside. Their arroz con gandules is sooo flavorful too. They give you huge portions and I come out stuffed but I always try my best to clean off my plate. I've never even had their dessert before. Compared to other restaurants in hoboken, this is pretty cheap. Around 20-30 bucks for huge lunch for 2 people (if you order drinks) or 30-40 for dinner (excluding wine). Awesome homey food, but I really do encourage you to have their lunch before you try their dinner though. Their dinner specials really aren't as special. Oh and their cuban sandwiches are amazing!  I want to try their stuffed french toast one day, rumor has it is that they're amazing. If you don't think this place is good for a date, you should reconsider. It's such a comfortable and non-stuffy environment that you end up talking so much over some really great food. Plus there's no awkward silence, just really great music at the right level. There's no better date than that. I don't encourage bringing babies though, the place is pretty cramped.

Always loved this place in when its only location was the little hole in the wall downtown. Now I prefer the uptown location where its more roomy and spacious. Food here never disappoints. Garlic chicken is amazing as are the yucca fries and the Tres Leches cake for dessert. Service can be hit or miss.

My girlfriend and I came on a Tuesday night around 8:30pm and we got the last table. It's a cozy place and the food was great! It had a very local feel to it and the staff was nice. Here's what we had:Papa Rellena - very delicious meat and potato on the inside while fried on the outside. I just added a little hot sauce to spicen it up.Cubano - The sandwich had a great combination of cheese, pork, ham, and pickles..it definitely hit the spot. I would come back for more!Flan - Thick and strong. It was different than the Spanish Flan that I'm used to. This was a good change because I always wondered what Cuban flan was like.Overall, great food at a great value! I'll come back to try different items on the menu.

Came here after grabbing baked goods from Carlos bakery right across the street.Came in around 4pm, and nothing on the lunch menu was available that we wanted to try (chicken we heard was very good, and I wanted to try to stew). They ran out of everything so we ordered sandwiches.Guy Ferrari and Bobby Flay also came by here so it was exciting to try, plus it's Cuban food!Must order the savannah or Habana sandwich... It was incredibly delish! Came with fried plantains that were slightly salted. 3 layers of butter toasted bread with mayo, avocado, meat, onions, and bacon. Also got the el Cubano sandwich, and the pork was dry. Didn't like it much, so they got me another Habana sandwich.Would like to come back when they have the food I want to try!

Not quite a hidden gem - as it was recognized on multiple TV shows - La Isla still maintains a quaint feeling. Its narrow storefront serves up some damn good Cuban sandwiches and plates. We dined al fresco mid-December thanks to this year's strange weather. It was a pleasant, appropriately slow moving experience. Start with a papa rellena - a lightly fried mashed potato and ground beef ball served with sweet salsa. It's an appetizer, but fairly large. They have excellent daily entrée specials. I forgot what it was that I ordered, but it was an excellent combination of braised beef, sweet potatoes, and rice. Very filling and delicious. I would definitely make an effort to come back for the brunch that is raved about by many.

Super delicious! I went today for the first time.  It was authentic and the service was top notch.  I felt like I was home.  If you are in the area,  please do yourself the favor.  Lunch hours are pretty busy but definitely worth it!
Ropa vieja and lechón con arroz phenomenal!!!!!!!!!! The food comes out quick too so no waiting time. Plus it's byob place

Been coming to la Isla for years for breakfast and never disappointed. I always get the churrasco and eggs, so good.  This restaurant is small and could get very crowded on Saturday mornings, so either come early (I know, not easy on Saturdays after a night in the City) or expect to wait, but worth it.  I really enjoy the coffee, nice and strong, the way I like it.  I haven't tried everything on the menu, but all the dishes I've tried were so good.  The French Toast is amazing and was featured on the Food Channel.

Don't order food for delivery. La Isla will minimize your food. You won't get what you'd usually get dine in. I've paid $19.00 for Camarillo (not including delivery) and received three pieces of shrimp with 2 ounces of sauce. The plantain on the side was 1/2 a banana.. Geez what a disappointment. I just wasted money.

The food is outstanding but the service and attitude of management is mediocre at best. Don't get me wrong, people are friendly... they just take a really long time to serve or acknowledge you, so if you are looking to eat soon or are in a bit hurry don't come here.Also, came in today for Brunch and had the steak and eggs (really good) but wanted some additional food, but the kitchen close at 2:50pm, despite brunch being advertised until 3:00pm.Again, good food and good people, terrible service and terrible management.

Never been here to eat but have stopped by several times to get some coffee. Definitely one of the best coffees I've had. The staff is always friendly and welcoming. Can't wait to go back and try the food.

Their palomilla steak was on point along with their cheesecake surrounded with mango purée and coconut shavings.The crust was very different; sweet like caramel which worked very well w/the cheesecake. The location is small and very busy for brunch, which you may end up being on a wait list. On weekdays they only offer their famous stuffed French toast until around 11am. The way they dip the French toast with cornflakes and almonds makes it so different from other stuffed French toasts. The toast itself has such a fabulous combination of subtle flavors that really come together. It's crunchy on the outside, soft on the inside. I felt it needed a little more cream cheese to better balance out the amount of strawberries in it's stuffing (this is just my opinion of course). Parking can be a nightmare during the brunch weekends. Everything tasted delicious and would recommend.

They sold me a spolied Flan. When I picked it up and brought it home, took 1 bite and almost threw up in my mouth. When I called and asked them to deliver me a new one (I live 2 blocks away). I was rejected.OK, ill pick it up. So I went to go pick it up and the owner/manager was there and took a bite of my flan right in front of me and confirmed it was spoiled! I asked them "do you make it fresh?" he said yes on the phone but in person the guy told me it was the only flan they sold that day. So, don't come here expecting fresh food. Also, dont expect them to believe you when you tell them food is spoiled. The only way to prove it is if they take a bite of your food. I was EXPECTING a refund, free dessert or something...what did I get? nothing? He gave me the tres leches dessert; which I really don't like but agreed to take. The portion is way too small to justify the price.Stay away; this place is terrible. No!

Excellent Cuban food each time we visit. Definitely better than Cafe Habana in the city, although La Isla does not have grilled corn. Brunch/breakfast here is always really busy, but worth the wait. For brunch, we tried the famous stuffed french toast (amazing), the huevos rancheros (pretty good), the churrasco and black beans (amazing), and the chorizo omelette (pretty good). Sister's boyfriend tried their cuban latte which he said was pretty damn good as well. For dinner, we've tried the cuban (huge, tasty sandwich for only $8), ceviche, tostones (favorite), tasajo con boniato (not worth the hype on ddd, but still good. meat was too salty. the sweet potatoes were the best part), churrasco con chimichurri (solid - nice and tender), and the frozen key lime pie (amazing). This has become one of our staple places to eat. Decent pricing and always fills you up.
Really simple review -- I really like this place. The food is terrific, the staff is super friendly, and the atmosphere is fun. I usually sit at the diner bar but there are also a few tables too.

This place was really awesome.For dinner i got A chicken empanada-a little bit of spice but just enough to keep it tasty, not to greasyTostones-a little greasy, but delicious.Papa Rellena-What in the hell have a been missing, a giant ball of mash potatoes and meat and breaded and fried.. sweet loving hell was this thing goodGarlic chicken-the sauce is unreal and the grilled chicken has a great taste to itOverall not too expensive, very reasonable and quick
Great cuban chicken. I'm excited that the uptown location is open!

I have to give 3 stars, because after hearing all of the raves about this place - they couldn't' serve me! I suffer from a severe mango allergy and when I explained this to our water, they wouldn't serve me.  It does make me question how clean this place really is.

I'm sure you can find a lot of Cuban restaurants that have the flash and ambience that La Isla lacks. However, you might not find one with cuisine as authentic!Thankfully, we came here on a Tuesday night because we have seen the lines outside this place on the weekend! Great food at great prices. Typical of what you find at authentic, "hole in the wall" joints, but in the middle of busy Hoboken. I'm certain that these recipes were handed down from generation to generation and its transparent in every bite. The veggie empanadas might have been better than the chicken! The Fritas were great, as well as the yellow rice and beans side. Awesome stuff, would wait to be seated!

Our go to for great Cuban food. Been going here for years and it never disappoints. Great empanadas, great rice and beans and awesome cuban sandwiches. The place is tiny but the counter service helps to accommodate diners wanting to chow down. Byob..........love La Isla!!!
Reminds me of the Cuban cafes I grew up on in Miami. These are few of my favorite things: cafe con leche, croquettas de jamon, the stuffed French toast, and the churasco. The food here is perfection.

The food is OK. Overpriced for what you are getting and the service was not good at all. The waitress dropped my drink on me and then I had to remind her and the busboy I needed something to clean myslef with. 5 minutes later. Cherry on the cake was that my phone was stolen there. I am 100% sure I forgot my phone on the table. It was close to closing hours and there weren't any other customers around me only the busboy cleaning tables. I went straight home after eating and know I left it on the table. I had 90% battery and when I called my phone after realizing I had forgotten it on the table, the phone was turned off. They were very rude to me when I called to ask about my phone and even accused me of lying. I spoke to the manager and he was not helpful at all, if anything he was very dismisive. Had they been the least bit sympathetic I would go back, but their attitutde towards me was very unappreciated.

I am obsessed with Cuban food and at times am a little critical.That said, this restaurant has a great advantage in Hoboken due to the lack of spanish food in the area. There is quite often a line out the door. This place is tiny and gets a ton of business.I have been here only a couple of times because I think it is too expensive. I often eat cuban food and rather go somewhere I can get big portions for smaller prices. At La Isla, the food is ok. I have had ropa vieja, rice and beans, and several breakfast items.  They are not bad, but not to die for. And being Colombian and a fanatic of latin food, I like to feel like I cant live without my favorite foods.
Heard a lot of good reviews about this place but I did not like the food much. I had the chicken sandwich it wasn't out of the world but wasn't bad either

Food was delicious, service was great.  Definitely recommend the potatoe/beef appitizer that was featured on the Food Network.  Note that its BYO, so if you want to drink make sure you bring something.

I've been living in Hoboken for over five years now and when I'm in the mood for the best breakfast in town, we go to La Isla. I would recommend a cafe con leche and either the La Isla breakfast sandwich or custom made omelette. The place has a truly unique Cuban feel and the servers always moving about with smiles on their faces. You will not be disappointed with your experience at La Isla!
Good restaurant. Very authentic Cuban food and very authentic atmosphere. The size of a small trailer with people crammed in only adds to the fun atmosphere. Fun little lunch place. Cuban is amazing.

BYOB and does not accept reservationsIt's very easy to miss this place. I've passed this place numerous times and have always just ignored it. I've been to the pizza place to its left a few times and to Cluck U to its right plenty of times as well completely ignoring this restaurant's existence. Apparently it's a famous restaurant that's been featured on tv and rightly so.It's not a fancy place but the food was surprisingly amazing. They also serve big portions for the price you pay. I found the plantains a bit dry though and the mango-y chimichurri was just alright. I had a very pleasant experience nevertheless and would still recommend this place to anyone in search of good Cuban food.

As many other reviews have stated this is one of the best Cuban restaurants around and I would venture to say easily the best Cuban north of Miami.  I've eaten here many times and have yet to find myself disappointed by anything that I've ordered.I've had dinner here a good dozen times and brunch once so I can't comment on the sandwiches at La Isla which people say are a big thing around here.  However, every dinner I've had has been fantastic and the prices are very reasonable ($14 for an entree with sides).  Add in the fact that it's BYOB with no corking fee and you got yourself a nice evening that won't put a dent into your pocket.Note, I had their French Toast (the one featured in the Food Network) and it was damn good and it was a happy dish.  It felt like waking up Saturday morning as a kid, watching cartoons and eating a bowl of Fruity Pebbles then using its milk for another bowl of Captain Crunch.  I don't know if that makes sense but let's just say it was a very nice indulgent breakfast.
Very high quality when it comes to the food. They don't skimp on anything and it shows on presentation as well as taste. Make sure you get the cafe con leche!!

Really great place, not so good for vegetarians at lunch or dinner, but what do you expect, it's authentic Cuban food.  The brunch is amazing, their huevos rancheros is delicious and the French toast is amazing!! I highly recommend if you're going for breakfast or brunch to get there early as there is always a line out the door. They don't take reservations.

I absolutely love the food here. They have two locations in Hoboken...this one is a BYOB and is small yet very authentic and casual. The other one on 13th, has a bar and is larger and fancier. If you have a party larger than 4, I'd head over there. It's great that no matter which location you choose, the food is the same, so it just depends what type of atmosphere you want. I personally enjoy this location better because it is BYOB. I've been here where I was sat right away and I've also had times where I had to wait about 30 minutes. The food is always impressive...they have truly authentic Cuban cuisine and never make you feel rushed when you are finishing your drinks! I am gluten free and have had no issues finding great options here, they are very accommodating and friendly. For $19 you get a huge steak and 2 sides, you can't beat that in Hoboken!

Omg all sorts of YESSSS. I'm usually not a sandwich person but their grilled chicken sandwich is to die for. And their French fries are one of the best I've ever tasted. The place is very small and sometimes crowded but the food is definitely worth it. I love it.

Great food!  Luckily, we were able to get a spot at the bar immediately - usually I know there is a really long wait.  As an appetizer got the papa reliena - omg it was amazing!  It looks like a fried ball but inside is mashed potatoes and ground meat - you must get this when you go there!  As an entrée we got a chicken sandwich - which yes I know, a chicken sandwich at a Mexican restaurant but it was soooo good!  The bread was fresh and the chicken was nicely grilled - it was delicious!  Also got the tasajo con boniato - which was also very delicious!  Had rice and meat on top - amazing!  I definitely recommend eating at La Isla - everyone is also so friendly and great service!  P.S. It is a BYOB
Nice Cuban food... The atmosphere is very relaxing with nice music... The black beans are fantastic... And the tostones is what you really need eat to feel at home...

A Hoboken classic. Always great. It reminds me of the best Cuban places in Miami. I've been going here for years and I've never had disappointing food or service. Consistency and reliability are what I want in a neighborhood place. I like it all but my favorites are the simple things like fried plantains and cafe con leche.

It's a refreshing change from your typical gentrified Hoboken establishment. (It's been a while since I've been, there may be a Starbucks inside now for all I know will update you soon!) I've never been disappointed at La Isla, fast, easy, cheap, delicious Cuban bocaditos. Authentic flavors, always on point with my palate.
Papa Rellenas were amazing. The Empanada de Pollo was alright.Very reasonably priced.

This is my... well, I can't keep count because that's how many times I've been here. I love just plainly ordering the sandwich. Today I ordered the Media Noche and it was pretty good. Although, the meat was a tad dry but the juicy pickles made up for it.  The prices are adequate. The place is small with only a handful of tables to sit in AND outside the restaurant. it's not really made to bring a large amount of people. Maybe a double date or something.  You guys need to try this place!

The world is a wonderful place due to the fact that La Isla Restaurant in Hoboken, NJ is still open.  Not sure why it wouldn't be.  It is hands down one of my favorite restaurants in Hoboken and I love that it is a mainstay on Washington Street and has been for years.It had been years since I walked through the doors of this place.  Actually probably a few years since my last time in Hoboken, a place I once called home.  Wasn't sure how different Washington Street (the main drag for those of you that have never been here) would be.  What was still in business?  What was long gone?  Happily La Isla is still part of the former category.Dad and I came to Hoboken to tool around a bit.  I wanted to see the old hood and catch up with a friend who works in this town.  We were in town around lunchtime and plans were made to meet up with this friend of mine.  We met him at his office building at which point a decision needed to be made as to where we were going to get lunch.  La Isla immediately came into my mind and after some deliberation the decision was made.I would like to call La Isla a dive, but in the best sense of the word.  It reminds me of places I've been to in the south of Florida.  Cuban.  Homey.  Wonderful.  To me there is almost nothing better than authentic.  Sure, I haven't been to Cuba, but I'm just going to go ahead and assume that this is authentic.Usually I might go with the Cuban Sandwich because I remember it to be pretty killer, but they have daily lunch specials so I decided to order from that menu.  Chicharron de Pollo ~ Marinated Fried Chicken Chunks ($8.50) and that comes with your choice of 2 of the following:  rice, beans, yuca, maduro.  I went with the black beans and the madura (plantains).The chicken was nice and tender.  More or less fried chicken as you know it.  The plantains were sweet and soft and the beans were prepared the way beans should be prepared.  Whatever that means.This is a pretty small and tight space.  We got lucky and walked in just as 2 tables were opening up.  They also have a counter area and you can grab a stool over there.  Weekends are busy, or at least from what I remember.  This is a very unique restaurant as far as Hoboken goes.  It stands out.  It is in a busy part of town.  They are putting out some good and affordable fare and I am so happy to know that they are still around.  Can't wait for my next trip back.

Had to try since they were on DDD! no wait on a Wednesday night - but we did have to sit at the bar which was fun since we could see some of the plates being prepared.  Staff was nice - made ate the water stayed full and didn't wait for anything.  We started with famous giant ball of potatoes and meat -papa rellena---- tasty. We got it with the sauce which I would recommend.  I had the cuban and he got the other main meal which they stayed on the menu was shown on DDD- tasajo con bonita I was not impressed with his meal but we both really liked the sandwich with the fried plantains on the side.  I would go back but probably only for apps and sandwiches.
My number one food place. There chefs and cooks are the best. perfectly made rice, beans, chicken, soups, cuban sandwiches , empanadas, and juice.

La Isla egg sandwich (egg, red onion, avocado, tomato, bacon on Cuban bread; of course, I ordered it without the bacon; the bread was awesome!! I loved how crispy the crust of the bread was and honestly, I have high expectations of this bread with a Cuban sandwich; the egg was nicely cooked and the sandwich itself was good; it was plain to a point but it was very clean, meaning that they didn't smother this sandwich in oil or sauce, what you read is exactly what you got; I had to add tobasco and ketchup in this or I wouldn't have enjoyed it as much)*Omar's stuffed french toast (egg bread filled with strawberry/guava cream cheese, dipped in cinnamon batter and coated with corn flakes and almonds; I did not enjoy this in the least bit; that cream cheese is SUPER sweet and gross; definitely glad I only got a taste of this and did not order this dish because I would not have enjoyed this; surprised that this would be on Bobby Flay's Throwdown though)*Cuban latte (I liked this coffee; it wasn't super strong or of a dark roast but it was still good and very smooth)We dined al fresco; the metal chairs I would do without since they were uncomfortable; the service was good; the place is ultra tiny but they manage to keep it clean and organized

Have only come here for breakfast, but this place is quick and delicious. The coffee (both hot & iced) is great, the Manchego, Onion & Chorizo omelette was fantastic and La Isla Egg Sandwich was tasty on the multigrain bread. Have always left satisfied and plan to return next time we're in Hoboken.

Hoboken needs more places like this: small, inexpensive, and delicious ethnic food. what a great hole in the wall!swung by yesterday with my friend Chris to grab lunch on my day off. there's maybe 20 or so seats in the whole place, so we ended up sitting at the counter. lunchtime here gets packed!we split a side of black beans and rice and each got a grilled sandwich. I went for the pan con bistec, a grilled steak sandwich with lettuce, tomatoes, onions, and crispy potato sticks. good quality meat, fresh veggies, and the potato sticks added a nice crunch to it. a good analogy is those french fry sticks you can buy at random bodegas and delis for like 50 cents (remember when they were just a quarter?), but these were made fresh. sandwich was pretty huge too! man, I was filled.price was cheap - we each threw in 11 bucks and were set. service was really fast. lunchtime is probably their peak time, and they handle it quite well.they have daily specials as well. roast chicken, grilled fish, stew, and more.this is definitely worth the wait time! hopefully the disgustingly high rent prices of Washington Street don't torpedo this restaurant's future!

The only drawback to this place is the size of the establishment.  Other than that, food is delish and the portions can feed 2.  I always have enough for lunch the next day!  Also their lunch specials are served till 9pm!! Can't beat that!! Friendly staff and awesome atmosphere.

I got the fritas and some rice and beans and it was all so yummy. The fritas are pretty simple but they were so amazing anyways and the potato sticks inside of it added a nice crunch to the sliders. My boyfriend also got the papa rellena and it was delish!!
This is one of the best restaurants in Hoboken. Grab a bottle of wine (byob), go sit outside in the summer, order some delicious cuban food, and watch the world go bye. Perfect date
